chapter: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In nasopharyngeal carcinoma, which of the following is a component of trotter's triad?

options.A: Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
options.B: Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
options.C: Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis
options.D: Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis hearing loss : Due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumour, leading to middle ear effusion. Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia : Caused by tumour infiltration into the base of the skull, affecting branches of the trigeminal nerve. Palatal paralysis : Resulting from involvement of the pharyngeal plexus or cranial nerves IX and X. Sensorineural hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis (Option B) : Sensorineural hearing loss is not typically seen in NPC unless there is advanced cranial nerve involvement. Neuralgia and paralysis are ipsilateral to the tumour, not contralateral. Sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis (Option C) : As mentioned, hearing loss in NPC is usually conductive, not sensorineural. Conductive hearing loss, contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, palatal paralysis (Option D) : While conductive hearing loss and palatal paralysis are consistent with NPC, the neuralgia is ipsilateral to the tumour, not contralateral. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, Page 297-298
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A female patient came with complaints of nasal obstruction, loss of smell and foul smelling nasal discharge. On examination, presence of yellowish-green crusts in the nasal cavity along with merciful anosmia is observed. Which of the following additional findings may be observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Roomy nasal cavity The patient's symptoms, nasal obstruction, anosmia (loss of smell), foul-smelling nasal discharge, and yellowish-green crusts , are highly suggestive of Atrophic Rhinitis . Atrophic Rhinitis is a chronic nasal condition characterized by: Progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinates Formation of thick, foul-smelling nasal crusts Merciful anosmia (patients are unaware of the foul smell) Roomy nasal cavity due to atrophy of nasal structures Nasal polyps (Option B): Incorrect because nasal polyps present with bilateral nasal obstruction , watery rhinorrhea, and no foul smell . They are soft, pale, and non-crusting, unlike the yellowish-green crusts in Atrophic Rhinitis. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy (Option C): Incorrect because Atrophic Rhinitis causes atrophy of the turbinates, not hypertrophy. Hypertrophy occurs in allergic rhinitis or chronic rhinitis , which presents with congestion rather than a foul-smelling discharge. Foreign body (Option D): Incorrect because a foreign body in the nose is more common in children and typically causes unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge , rather than bilateral atrophic changes seen in Atrophic Rhinitis. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 8th Edition • Page no: 178, 179, 200
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered a major diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal sinusitis?
questions.explanation: diagnosing allergic fungal sinusitis, fungal culture is a minor criterion. Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS): Non-invasive fungal disease commonly affects younger individuals, especially those in warm, humid climates and lower socio-economic conditions. Common causative organism: Aspergillus . Atopic individuals are more prone to AFRS. Symptoms: Unilateral or bilateral nasal congestion, post-nasal drip, and thick, dark nasal discharge. CT Scan: Shows pansinusitis, hyper attenuated intrasinus contents (allergic mucin), and potential erosion of sinus walls due to inflammation. Bent and Kuhn Diagnostic Criteria for AFRS: Major Criteria (must meet all) Minor Criteria (supportive) Type I hypersensitivity (history, skin test, or in vitro testing) Nasal polyposis (Option A) Characteristic CT findings (Option C ruled out) Eosinophilic mucin without fungal invasion (Option B ruled out) Positive fungal stain (Option D ruled out) Asthma Unilateral disease Radiological bone erosion Fungal cultures (Option A) Serum eosinophilia Charcot-Leyden crystals Reference: Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition, Pg - 212

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.explanation: causing erosion or remodeling of adjacent bony structures, such as the nasal septum or the walls of the sinuses. Inverted papilloma is a benign sinonasal tumor that arises from the lining of the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses. It often presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, recurrent nosebleeds, and the potential for locally aggressive behavior. Inverted Papilloma Origin Arises from the non-olfactory mucosa (Schneiderian membrane) of the nasal

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a person who has facial swelling and orbital edema on the left side of their face after a minor trauma involving a piece of wood 20 days ago? The CT scan showed no abnormalities in the sinuses but revealed subcutaneous nodules. Microscopic examination of tissue sections showed positivity for PAS stain and Grocott's methenamine silver stain.
questions.explanation: phycomycosis caused by fungi in the Mucorales. It typically affects immunocompromised individuals and can manifest as rhinocerebral, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, or cutaneous infection. The clinical presentation described in the question, with facial swelling, orbital edema, and subcutaneous nodules, along with the histological findings of PAS-positive and Grocott's methenamine silver-positive staining, is suggestive phycomycosis. Mucormycosis Description A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit,

questions.question: Choose the best description for the structure marked in the CT given below.
questions.explanation: turbinate. Pneumatization of the superior turbinate, also known as superior concha bullosa, is a relatively rare anatomical variation where air cells develop within the superior turbinate. Symptoms In most cases, pneumatization of the superior turbinate is asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging studies for other reasons. Nasal obstruction or congestion Headache Sinusitis Smell disorders Diagnosis Best diagnosed with a computed tomography (CT) scan of the paranasal sinuses. Agger nasi cell (Option A): The agger nasi is an ethmoidal air cell situated in front of the uncinate process. The degree of pneumatization of this cell determines the thickness of the nasofrontal beak and the position of the superior uncinate process. Onodi cell (Option C): An Onodi cell, also known as a sphenoethmoidal or lateral sphenoid sinus cell, is an anatomical variation where the sphenoid sinus extends laterally to involve the posterior ethmoid sinus. Haller cell (Option D): A Haller cell is an anterior ethmoid air cell that extends into the floor of the orbit, near the ethmoidal bulla and frontal recess. Reference: Role of Superior Turbinate Pneumatisation in Chronic Rhinosinusitis - PMC Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 159
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Little's area?

options.A: Keisselbach’s plexus is present in the Little’s area
options.B: It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum
options.D: Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Keisselbach’s plexus is present in the Little’s area Explanation: Little's area , also known as Kiesselbach's plexus , is a highly vascular region located in the anterior part of the nasal septum. It is a site of frequent epistaxis (nosebleeds) due to the rich network of blood vessels that anastomose here. Keisselbach's plexus is a network of arteries formed by anastomoses of branches from the internal carotid artery (like the sphenopalatine artery ) and the external carotid artery (including the superior labial artery and anterior ethmoidal artery ), which supply the nasal septum. Kiesselbach’s plexus, also known as Little's area , is a highly vascularised region in the anteroinferior portion of the nasal septum , where multiple arteries converge. It is the most common site of anterior epistaxis , especially in children and young adults. Vessels involved in forming the plexus Artery Branch of Sphenopalatine artery Maxillary artery Anterior ethmoidal artery Ophthalmic artery (from internal carotid artery) Greater palatine artery Maxillary artery Superior labial artery Facial artery (from external carotid artery) Note: Posterior ethmoidal artery is not part of this plexus Clinical Significance: Anterior epistaxis occurs most often in children and young adults, usually due to trauma (nose-picking), dry air, infections, or irritants. Epistaxis in this area is typically mild and self-limiting and can be controlled with local pressure or simple cauterization. It is situated at the posteroinferior part of the nasal septum (Option B) : is incorrect because Little's area is located at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, not the posterior. Least common site for epistaxis (Option C) : is incorrect because Little's area is the most common site for epistaxis, not the least. Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here (Option D) : is incorrect because the anastomoses of the major arteries involved in Little’s area are primarily derived from the internal and external carotid arteries, but not seven arteries. The arteries involved are generally 4-5, not seven.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 14-year-old male who has been experiencing repeated nosebleeds, without any history of injury, along with nasal blockage and excessive nasal discharge? During examination, a solid, purplish growth is observed on the back of the nasopharynx.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma Explanation: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: This benign but locally aggressive vascular tumour occurs predominantly in adolescent males. It commonly presents with repeated episodes of epistaxis (nosebleeds) , nasal obstruction , and sometimes nasal discharge . Examination often reveals a solid, vascular, purplish mass in the nasopharynx. This is the most probable diagnosis in a 14-year-old male with these symptoms and findings. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) Site of Origin Posterior nasal cavity, near the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen, where the sphenoid and palatine bones meet. Gross Appearance Reddish-purple, lobulated, sessile mass covered by mucosa; lacks a capsule despite being benign. Microscopic Appearance Vascular Tissue: Endothelium-lined spaces with incomplete/absent muscle coats, leading to bleeding; peripheral vessels are thin-walled, central vessels hyperplastic. Stromal Cells: Stellate or spindle-shaped cells that produce collagen, affecting tumor firmness. Immunohistochemistry Fibroblasts, collagen, myofibroblasts, mast cells, and occasionally giant cells are present. Reactivity to smooth muscle actin and beta-catenin, suggesting beta-catenin’s role in growth. Growth Factors JNA development likely results from a combination of hormonal influence, growth factors, and genetic factors. Androgen Receptors: Present in 75% of JNA tumors, indicating male hormone involvement. VEGF: Promotes endothelial and stromal cell growth. IGF-II: Role is less clear. Genetics: C-MYC proto-oncogene found in larger tumors; may interact with androgen receptor and beta-catenin genes. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option A): This malignant tumour usually occurs in older adults and is rare in this age group. It often presents with neck lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, or ear symptoms but is unlikely to present with a solid, vascular growth in a young male. Rhabdomyosarcoma (Option B): This is a malignant soft tissue tumour that can occur in the nasopharynx but is rare and less likely to cause repeated epistaxis without systemic signs like weight loss or fatigue. Pyogenic granuloma (Option C): This is a vascular lesion but typically occurs on the nasal septum or oral mucosa, not in the nasopharynx. It is usually smaller, friable, and more superficial. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, Page 289-291
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which is the most common site for head and neck cancer in India?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Oral cavity Explanation: In India, the oral cavity is the most common site for head and neck cancer. This high prevalence is largely attributed to the widespread use of tobacco in various forms (smoking, chewing, betel quid) and alcohol consumption. Poor oral hygiene and HPV infection are also contributory factors. Nasopharynx (Option A) : While nasopharyngeal carcinoma is relatively common in some regions (e.g., Southeast Asia), it is not the most common site of head and neck cancer in India. Oropharynx (Option B) : Oropharyngeal cancers, including those involving the tonsils and base of the tongue, are associated with HPV infection but are less common than oral cavity cancers in India. Hypopharynx (Option D) : Hypopharyngeal cancers are associated with smoking and alcohol use but are less frequent than oral cavity cancers in the Indian population. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page 814, 815
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a patient who arrives at the emergency department with epistaxis, despite unsuccessful attempts to stop the bleeding by pinching the nostrils and nasal packing?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Ligation of sphenopalatine artery Epistaxis (nosebleed) that persists despite pinching the nostrils and nasal packing suggests posterior epistaxis , which is often due to bleeding from the sphenopalatine artery . The sphenopalatine artery is the main arterial supply to the nasal cavity, making it the primary target for surgical intervention in refractory cases. Management Approach: Initial Management Pinching nostrils (first-line conservative treatment) Nasal packing (anterior and posterior) If Nasal Packing Fails Endoscopic ligation or cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery is the preferred next step. If Epistaxis Persists Ligation of the external carotid artery may be considered as a last resort. Ligation of external carotid artery (Option A): Incorrect because sphenopalatine artery ligation is more effective and less invasive . External carotid artery ligation is reserved for extreme, uncontrolled cases . Ligation of internal carotid artery (Option B): Incorrect because this is very high-risk , associated with stroke and severe complications , and is not required for managing epistaxis. Ligation of maxillary artery (Option D): Incorrect because while the maxillary artery supplies the sphenopalatine artery , directly ligating the sphenopalatine artery is more targeted and less morbid . Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 8th Edition • Page no: 208-210 Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition : Volume 1: Basic Sciences, Endocrine Surgery, Rhinology • Page no: 1175-1178
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the view that provides the optimal visualization of the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Water’s view Explanation: Water's view (also known as the occipitomental view) is the radiographic projection that provides the best visualization of the maxillary sinus. This view is obtained by having the patient tilt their head back, with the chin raised and the X-ray beam directed at the patient’s face. It allows optimal imaging of the maxillary sinus, as it projects the sinus clearly and eliminates superimposition of other structures. View Position Purpose Image Waters' View (Occipitomental View) Chin-up position. Best view to visualize the maxillary sinus. Pierre’s View Similar to Waters' view but with the mouth open . Best view to visualize the sphenoid sinus. Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View) Chin-down position. Best view to visualize the frontal sinus. Lateral View Lateral (as the name indicates) Allows visualization of all sinuses (frontal, maxillary, sphenoid, and ethmoidal). Helps to understand the pneumatization pattern of the sphenoid sinus. Incorrect Options: Towne’s view (Option B) : Towne's view is used primarily for imaging the skull, particularly the occipital region, and is not specifically for the maxillary sinus. Law’s view (Option C) : Law's view is used to assess the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) and not for the maxillary sinus. Stenver’s view (Option D) : Stenver’s view is used to image the petrous portion of the temporal bone and is not ideal for visualizing the maxillary sinus.

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for an older diabetic woman,who received steroids and remdesivir for COVID, and is now experiencing a malodorous black discharge from her nose? On examination a necrotic black mass, filling the nasal cavity and causing erosion of the septum and hard palate is found.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Mucormycosis Explanation: The most likely diagnosis for an older diabetic woman with a malodorous black discharge from the nose, a necrotic black mass filling the nasal cavity, and erosion of the septum and hard palate is mucormycosis . This is a severe fungal infection caused by molds from the Mucoraceae family, often affecting immunocompromised individuals, such as those with diabetes, receiving steroids, and having viral infections like COVID-19. Mucormycosis commonly presents with: Nasal or sinus involvement (as seen with black, necrotic tissue and discharge). Erosion of surrounding structures, such as the septum and palate. A rapidly progressive course, especially in diabetic and immunocompromised patients. Malodorous discharge due to tissue necrosis. Mucormycosis Description A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction. Characteristic Findings Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI. Risk Factors Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment) Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues. Diagnosis Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing. Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features. Imaging CT : Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement. CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction. MRI : Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain . Treatment Antifungal Therapy : Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day. Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily. Surgical Intervention : Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues. Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required. Incorrect Options: Aspergillosis (Option A) : Aspergillosis is another fungal infection, but it typically does not present with black necrotic masses. It is more commonly associated with chronic sinusitis or allergic reactions, not with necrosis and tissue destruction seen here. Foreign body (Option C) : A foreign body might cause a localized obstruction and discharge but would not lead to the extensive necrosis and erosion of the nasal cavity, septum, and palate as described in this case. Rhinosporidiosis (Option D) : Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi , typically involving the nasal mucosa. It causes polypoidal growths, not necrotic black masses. It is more common in endemic areas, such as India and Sri Lanka.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Identify the sinus marked in the image.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Maxillary sinus Explanation: The maxillary sinus is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, located within the maxilla (upper jaw bone). It is pyramid-shaped and lies lateral to the nasal cavity, with its base forming the lateral wall of the nose and its apex extending towards the zygomatic bone. On radiographic or anatomical images, it appears as a large, air-filled cavity inferior to the orbit and lateral to the nasal cavity. Key features of the maxillary sinus: Largest paranasal sinus. Drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity through the semilunar hiatus. Commonly involved in sinusitis due to the high location of its drainage opening. The maxillary sinus or the Antrum of Highmore , is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, occupying the body of the maxilla. Shape - Pyramidal Size - 15mL Base - toward the lateral wall of the nose Apex - extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone Relations: Anterior wall: Formed by the facial surface of the maxilla. Posterior wall: Anterior surface of pterygopalatine fossa. Medial wall: Thin and membranous in some areas, this wall borders the middle and inferior meatuses and separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity. Roof: Formed by the floor of the orbit Floor: Located approximately 1 cm below the floor of the nasal cavity, it is formed by the alveolar and palatine processes of the maxilla. Closely related to the roots of the second premolar and first molar teeth. Cavities in these teeth are associated with oro antral fistula. Arterial supply: Branches of the maxillary artery, specifically the infraorbital artery, greater palatine artery, and the posterior superior alveolar artery. Venous drainage: Pterygoid venous plexus and the facial vein. Lymphatic drainage: Submandibular lymph nodes. Nerve supply: Infraorbital nerve, greater palatine nerve, and the posterior superior alveolar nerve, which are branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2). Incorrect Options: Frontal sinus (Option A) : Located

questions.question: What is the recommended course of action for managing a 6-year-old boy who fell from a bed and now has swelling in his nose, along with breathing difficulties? During examination, it was observed that there are smooth, rounded swellings on both sides of the septum, visible through both nostrils. On palpation, the swellings were found to be soft and fluctuant.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Incision and drainage Explanation: The clinical presentation of a 6-year-old boy with swelling in the nose, breathing difficulties, smooth and rounded swellings on both sides of the septum, and soft, fluctuant masses suggests the presence of a septal hematoma . Septal hematomas occur due to trauma, such as a fall, and can result in blood collection between the cartilage and mucosa of the nasal septum. The treatment of choice for septal hematomas is incision and drainage . If left untreated, septal hematomas can lead to complications such as abscess formation, nasal deformities, or even septal perforation due to cartilage necrosis. Septal Hematoma Aetiology Collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. Commonly caused by: Nasal trauma. Septal surgery. Spontaneous occurrence in bleeding disorders. Clinical features Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common symptom). Frontal headache and pressure over the nasal bridge. Smooth, rounded, soft, and fluctuant swelling in both nasal fossae (or sometimes unilateral). Treatment Small hematomas: Aspirated with a wide-bore sterile needle. Larger hematomas: Incision and drainage via a septal incision parallel to the nasal floor, excising a small piece of mucosa for better drainage. Nasal packing on both sides to prevent reaccumulation. Systemic antibiotics to prevent septal abscess. Complications Fibrous tissue formation leads to permanent septal thickening if untreated. Secondary infection may lead to septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and nasal dorsum depression. Incorrect Options: Systemic antibiotics (Option A) : While systemic antibiotics might be used if there is evidence of infection, antibiotics alone would not address the hematoma or swelling in this case. Drainage is necessary to prevent further complications. High-resolution computerized tomography (Option C) : CT imaging is typically not required for the diagnosis or management of a septal hematoma. A clinical examination is sufficient to make the diagnosis. CT may be considered if there is suspicion of fractures or other complex injuries, but it's not necessary in this straightforward case. Submucosal resection (Option D) : Submucosal resection is a procedure used in the treatment of nasal obstructions or deformities, often due to structural issues like a deviated septum. It is not appropriate for managing a septal hematoma, which requires drainage rather than resection.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which is not used for testing olfaction?
questions.explanation: cough reflex is an involuntary cough reflex due to the stimulation of the external ear. It is mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve). Insertion of a cotton bud or touching the external ear activates the nerve and evokes a forceful cough. Hence, the name 'Arnold stick'. It is not used to assess olfaction. UPSIT Test is University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test: (Option C ruled out) It is a subjective test to assess smell perception. Patients are given scratch cards of odorous stimuli to identify. It is used to diagnose olfactory dysfunction associated with certain diseases. Tests done to assess nasal airflow: Subjective Tests: Nasal Airflow Questionnaire Visual Analog Scale (VAS) Objective Tests: Rhinomanometry Acoustic Rhinometry Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF) Tests done for smell perception: University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) Sniffin' Sticks Test CC-SIT (Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test) (Option D ruled out) Smell diskettes (Option A ruled out) Odor Threshold Test Olfactory Event-Related Potentials (OERP) Reference: Updated Percentiles for the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK565861/
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. She has a history of FESS following failed conservative management 5 years ago. Post-surgical notes mentioned that uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation were done during the previous FESS. DNE currently shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation: with symptoms suggestive of recurrent or persistent rhinosinusitis despite previous functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS). The key finding is mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining with patent ostia. This suggests inflammation as the primary issue, not anatomical obstruction. Since the ostia are patent, drainage is not the problem, making further surgery less likely to be beneficial at this stage. Hence, it requires antihistamines and steroid irrigation. Steroid irrigation reduces mucosal edema and antihistamines help in controlling allergic symptoms and mucosal edema. Non-Allergic Rhinitis: Treatment Non-allergic rhinitis presents with symptoms similar to allergic rhinitis (nasal obstruction, rhinorrhoea, sneezing) but without positive allergy tests. Treatment is categorised into medical and surgical options. Medical Treatment: Treatment Type Details Lifestyle Modifications Avoid triggers such as sudden temperature changes, humidity, air blasts, and dust. Practical changes to minimise symptom triggers Pharmacological Management Antihistamines and Decongestants: Alleviate nasal obstruction, sneezing, and rhinorrhoea. Topical Steroid Sprays: Control Symptoms. Eg. Beclomethasone dipropionate, budesonide, fluticasone Systemic Steroids: Used for severe cases for a short time Ipratropium Bromide Nasal Spray: Effective for Excessive Rhinorrhoea. Psychological Support Address emotional factors; consider counselling and tranquillisers. Repeat surgery (Option A): Repeat surgery is not indicated in this scenario as it could be initially conservatively managed with steroid irrigation and antihistamines. Later, if the symptoms persist, surgical management can be considered . Macrolides for 4 months (Option B): It is prescribed in case of chronic rhinosinusitis. Biological therapy (Option D): Biological therapy is indicated only in severe refractory cases which show symptoms of active inflammation Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 178,198, 223
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A male patient presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a history of cough, on-and-off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with granulations in the nose. His chest X-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and necrosis. What is the probable cause?
questions.explanation: respiratory tract involvement (saddle nose, septal perforation), lower respiratory tract involvement (cough, hemoptysis, cavitary lesions), and the biopsy findings (granulomas, multinucleated giant cells, and necrosis) strongly points towards Wegener's granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis). Granulomatosis with polyangiitis: Previously known as Wegener’s granulomatosis. It is a systemic granulomatous inflammation and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels. More common in Caucasians (90%). Clinical features: Upper respiratory tract symptoms: Clear or purulent bloody nasal discharge Sinusitis On examination, crusting, granulations, septal perforation, and a saddle nose. Lower respiratory tract symptoms: cough, pleuritic pain, and hemoptysis. kidneys: Hematuria, later renal failure. Oral: ‘strawberry’ gingival hyperplasia is said to be pathognomonic. Skin: ulceration and nodules. Diagnosis: Chest X-ray: Nodules, fixed infiltrates or cavities Urine analysis: Microscopic haematuria with or without red cell casts. Biopsy: Necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma, and necrotizing vasculitis involving small arteries or veins. c-ANCA (cytoplasmic ANCA): Positive in 90% of the cases. p-ANCA (perinuclear ANCA): Positive in 10% of the cases. CT and MRI: Non-specific mucosal thickening in the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses, bone destruction, and new bone formation in the walls of the sinus cavities. Treatment: Systemic corticosteroids. Cyclophosphamide, azathioprine, methotrexate and rituximab are used. Tuberculosis (Option B): While TB can cause granulomas, the combination of nasal destruction (septal perforation, saddle nose) with lung cavities is more characteristic of GPA. TB can present with hemoptysis, but it's less commonly associated with the rapid destruction of nasal cartilage leading to saddle nose deformity as seen in GPA. Syphilis (Option C): Congenital syphilis can cause a saddle nose deformity. However, the other symptoms described (cough, hemoptysis, cavitary lung lesions, and the specific biopsy findings) are not typical of syphilis. Also, lung involvement is not a common presentation of syphilis. Sarcoidosis (Option D): Sarcoidosis is a multisystem granulomatous disease that can affect the lungs and upper respiratory tract. While it can cause granulomas on biopsy and lung involvement, it's less likely to cause destructive nasal changes like saddle nose deformity and septal perforation. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition- Pg No. 187. Scott Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, 8th Edition- Pg No. 1214-17. Harrison’s Principle of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition- Pg No. 2738
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the subsequent tests is not applicable for evaluating nasal mucociliary clearance?
questions.explanation: assess nasal mucociliary clearance. Electron microscopy can be used to examine the cilia of the epithelium. Saccharine test (Option A): This test helps in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance. Saccharin is placed around 1 cm behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate. The saccharin is swept back into the nasopharynx and perceived as a sweet taste. This suggests an intact/good mucociliary clearance. If the patient perceives the taste after 10-20 minutes, it indicates a delayed mucociliary clearance. Charcoal powder method (Option C): This helps in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance. In this test, 10 micrograms of charcoal are kept 1 cm behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The patient is asked to inhale the charcoal particles. It is seen deposited over the respiratory epithelium. Every 30 seconds, the posterior pharyngeal wall is observed for a blackish discoloration. After 30 minutes to 1 hour, the patient is asked to expectorate. The sputum is then examined for charcoal particles. Scintigraphy (Option D): I t involves the administration of radioactive tracers like technetium-99c DTPA which is instilled into the respiratory tract. A gamma camera is used to visualize the movement of the tracer through the respiratory pathway Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8916846/
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following least likely causes nasal septal perforation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Seasonal influenza Explanation: Seasonal influenza is the least likely cause of nasal septal perforation. While influenza can lead to symptoms like nasal congestion, sore throat, and fever, it typically does not result in nasal septal perforation. This condition is more often associated with chronic inflammation, infection, or trauma to the nasal septum, such as in cases of rhinosporidiosis, syphilis, or tuberculosis. Causes of Nasal Septal Perforation : Nasal septal perforation is a hole or rupture in the nasal septum, the cartilage and bone that divides the two nostrils. Several conditions can lead to this, including: Rhinosporidiosis : This is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by the fungus Rhinosporidium seeberi , often affecting the nasal mucosa and leading to the development of polyps or perforations in the nasal septum. Syphilis : A sexually transmitted infection caused by Treponema pallidum , syphilis can cause granulomatous inflammation, particularly in the tertiary stage, leading to nasal septal perforation (a manifestation of gumma). Tuberculosis : This chronic bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis can result in chronic granulomatous inflammation, leading to nasal septal perforation as part of the disease process, especially in advanced cases. Seasonal influenza (Option B) : is incorrect because while it causes acute viral upper respiratory tract infections, it does not typically result in chronic inflammation or tissue destruction that would lead to septal perforation. Incorrect Options: Rhinosporidiosis (Option A) : is incorrect because this fungal infection is a well-known cause of nasal septal perforation due to chronic inflammation and polyp formation. Syphilis (Option C) : is incorrect because tertiary syphilis can cause granulomatous lesions, including perforation of the nasal septum. Tuberculosis (Option D) : is incorrect because tuberculosis, particularly in its chronic form, can cause nasal septal perforation due to granulomatous inflammation. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 6th Edition Page no. 174 https://www.archivesofpathology.org/doi/pdf/10.5858/arpa.2015-0165-RA
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which clinical test is being shown in the image?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Cottle’s test. Explanation: Cottle’s Test is a diagnostic maneuver used to evaluate nasal obstruction, particularly to assess the patency of the nasal passages and nasal valve function . During this test, the examiner applies external pressure to the lateral nasal walls (just below the cheekbone) to temporarily relieve nasal obstruction. If this improves the patient’s airflow, it suggests nasal valve collapse or dysfunction, which is often seen in patients with deviated septum or nasal valve stenosis . Cottle’s Test: Cottle's test involves applying pressure to the lateral nasal wall while the patient is instructed to breathe in. If improvement in nasal airflow is noted when external pressure is applied, it indicates that nasal valve collapse is the cause of the obstruction. This test is frequently used before performing surgical interventions , such as septoplasty or rhinoplasty , to confirm the diagnosis of nasal valve insufficiency . Incorrect Options: Epley’s maneuver (Option A) : is incorrect because it is used for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) , not for nasal or facial assessments. Heimlich maneuver (Option B) : is incorrect because it is used for airway obstruction due to choking, not for assessing nasal function. Trotter’s method (Option D) : is incorrect because it is a clinical sign of nasopharyngeal carcinoma , characterized by trismus and nasal obstruction but not a diagnostic maneuver like Cottle's test.

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the sign depicted in the contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head shown below in a 14-year-old football player who presented to the casualty with complaints of epistaxis while playing football, along with a history of recurrent spontaneous nasal bleeding, unilateral nasal obstruction, and denasal speech, without any history of trauma or falls?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B- Holman Miller Sign. Explanation: Holman Miller Sign is associated with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) , a highly vascular benign tumor commonly seen in young males. It appears on imaging, typically on a contrast-enhanced CT scan, as a vascular mass in the nasopharynx or nasal cavity , and is indicative of JNA, which is associated with recurrent epistaxis , unilateral nasal obstruction , and denasal speech . Holman Miller Sign: Holman Miller Sign refers to the contrast-enhanced CT finding that highlights the vascular nature of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) . It is seen as a highly vascular mass in the nasopharyngeal region , often extending into the nasal cavity. JNA presents with recurrent epistaxis , nasal obstruction , denasal speech , and is often diagnosed in adolescent males . JNA is a benign tumor but can cause significant morbidity due to its location and vascularity. Treatment typically involves surgical resection and sometimes preoperative embolization to reduce vascularity. Incorrect Options: Aquino Sign (Option A): is incorrect because it is not

questions.question: A middle-aged man presents with complaints of a facial deformity, as shown in the image below. His medical records show a history of acne rosacea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A- Rhinophyma Explanation: Rhinophyma is a severe form of acne rosacea and is characterized by the thickening and enlargement of the nasal skin, often with a bulbous appearance. It is more common in men and typically develops in individuals with a long history of rosacea. The condition causes facial deformity due to the increased sebaceous gland activity and inflammation. The nose becomes enlarged and may appear red and nodular, which is consistent with the image shown. Rhinophyma: Rhinophyma is a subtype of acne rosacea , often associated with long-term rosacea that leads to the hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands on the nose. This condition manifests as: Thickening of the skin , leading to a bulbous or enlarged nose. Redness or telangiectasias (visible blood vessels) on the nose. It typically affects middle-aged to older men and is often triggered or worsened by chronic inflammation from acne rosacea. Treatment may involve laser therapy , surgical excision , or topical treatments to reduce the size and appearance of the nose. Incorrect Options: Rhinoscleroma (Option B) : is incorrect because rhinoscleroma is a chronic bacterial infection (caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae ) that leads to granulomatous inflammation and fibrosis, affecting the nasal and upper respiratory tract. It does not present with the same cosmetic deformity seen in rhinophyma. Rhinosporidiosis (Option C) : is incorrect because rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the Rhinosporidium seeberi , which leads to the development of polyps, not the thickening and deformity of the nose characteristic of rhinophyma. Scleroderma (Option D): is incorrect because scleroderma primarily causes skin tightening and fibrosis but does not lead to the characteristic redness and bulbous deformity of the nose seen in rhinophyma. Scleroderma can affect the face, but it does not
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for a 70-year-old man who has neck nodes and exhibits a dull tympanic membrane, along with symptoms of deafness and tinnitus in the left ear, and a type B graph on tympanometry?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma Explanation: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) commonly presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, which can explain the neck nodes observed in this patient. The patient also exhibits a dull tympanic membrane, which can be associated with eustachian tube dysfunction , a common manifestation in NPC due to obstruction or invasion of the nasopharynx. This dysfunction leads to middle ear effusion and the type B tympanogram seen in this case. The presence of deafness and tinnitus further suggests that the nasopharyngeal carcinoma may be affecting the middle ear or the auditory pathway. Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (NPC): Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor arising from the epithelial cells of the nasopharynx. It is more common in certain geographic regions and in older individuals. The disease often presents with: Cervical lymphadenopathy (neck nodes), as seen in this patient. Deafness or tinnitus , due to eustachian tube obstruction , which leads to middle ear effusion, presenting with a dull tympanic membrane. Type B tympanogram , which indicates middle ear effusion or obstruction. Incorrect Options: Chronic suppurative otitis media (Option A) : is incorrect because this condition typically causes a purulent discharge and would not lead to the characteristic lymphadenopathy or dull tympanic membrane associated with NPC. Glomus tumor (Option B) : is incorrect because although it can cause tinnitus and middle ear effusion, it would not typically present with cervical lymphadenopathy or the eustachian tube dysfunction leading to type B tympanogram. Sensorineural hearing loss (Option D): is incorrect because while it can cause hearing loss, the additional findings of cervical lymphadenopathy, a dull tympanic membrane, and type B tympanogram point toward a more localized pathology, such as NPC. Reference: Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th edition, pages 296-298
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: At what age frontal sinuses appear on X ray?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D- 4 years Explanation: The frontal sinuses are usually not visible on X-ray until around 4 years of age . While their development begins earlier, they do not appear clearly on radiographs until this age, as the sinuses are still small and continue to grow throughout childhood. Development of Paranasal Sinuses: Maxillary Sinus : The maxillary sinus is the first to develop and is present at birth as a small cavity. It grows rapidly during the early years of life and reaches full size by 4 years of age . Ethmoid Sinus : The ethmoid sinus is present as a small cluster of cells at birth and becomes more prominent in childhood. Development continues up to 6-8 years , with further changes through adolescence. Sphenoid Sinus : The sphenoid sinus begins to develop around 2 years of age. It is typically visible on imaging after 3-5 years and reaches its adult size by 12 years . Frontal Sinus : The frontal sinuses are not visible on imaging until about 4 years of age , with full development occurring much later, generally by the age of 16-18 years . Their growth continues until late adolescence. Incorrect Options: 1 year (Option A) : is incorrect because frontal sinuses are not present or visible on X-ray at this age. 2 years (Option B) : is incorrect because while they start developing around this time, they aren't visible on X-ray yet. 3 years (Option C) : is incorrect because although they begin developing around 2 years, frontal sinuses generally appear on X-ray by the age of 4 years , not 3 years. Reference: https://news.ncsu.edu/2017/06/05/frontal-sinus-forensic-2017/ https://journal.zums.ac.ir/browse.php?a_id=6215&sid=1&slc_lang=en&html=1
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Rhinolalia clausa occurs in all except:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C- Cleft palate Explanation: Rhinolalia clausa refers to a nasal voice or nasal speech caused by obstruction of the nasal passage . It occurs when there is impaired airflow through the nasal cavity during speech, resulting in a distinctive "blocked" or muffled sound. This condition is typically caused by nasal obstruction or nasopharyngeal pathology . Rhinolalia Clausa : Nasopharyngeal polyp , nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option B) , and nasopharyngeal angiofibroma are all conditions that can obstruct the nasopharyngeal region , leading to nasal speech (rhinolalia clausa). A cleft palate , however, leads to a different type of speech disorder . It causes velopharyngeal insufficiency , which results in hypernasality (excessive nasal resonance) rather than the nasal blockage seen in rhinolalia clausa. Incorrect Options: Nasopharyngeal polyp (Option A) : is incorrect because it can cause obstruction in the nasal passage, leading to rhinolalia clausa . Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Option B) : is incorrect because it can obstruct the nasopharynx, leading to nasal voice or rhinolalia clausa . Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option D) : is incorrect because it can obstruct the nasopharynx, leading to nasal speech or rhinolalia clausa . Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Pg - 286,287 Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition, Pg - 287
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B- 5-7 days following injury Explanation: In the case of a nasal fracture , the ideal time for closed reduction is typically within 5-7 days following the injury. This time frame allows for the initial swelling to subside , providing better visibility and ensuring that the fractured bones can be accurately realigned. Reducing the fracture within this window also minimizes the risk of complications and ensures better cosmetic and functional outcomes. Timing of Nasal Fracture Reduction : Early reduction (within the first 12 hours ) may sometimes be appropriate for fractures with significant deformity or in cases where swelling is minimal. However, it's generally not advisable to reduce the fracture within the first few hours because the swelling can obscure proper alignment and make it harder to achieve a precise reduction. After 5-7 days , when swelling decreases, a closed reduction can be safely performed, and the nasal bones can be realigned without much obstruction from edema. If the reduction is done too late (e.g., after 2 weeks or more), bony consolidation begins, making the bones harder to manipulate, and the chances of achieving an optimal result decrease. Incorrect Options: Within 12 hours following the injury (Option A) : is incorrect because early reduction is often difficult due to swelling that can hinder the realignment of the nasal bones. After 2 weeks of injury (Option C) : is incorrect because waiting too long increases the risk of bony consolidation , making it harder to reduce the fracture and improving the chances of a less satisfactory result. After 4 weeks of injury (Option D) : is incorrect for the same reason. At this point, the bones may have healed or begun to heal, which would reduce the success rate of reduction. Reference: Scott-Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition - 2018 Page 1612 P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 7th Edition Page 204 P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 8th Edition Page 213
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A boy fell down while playing and presented with deviated nose. The septum however was found to be normal. Following is the CT finding of the patient. What is the next step in management?

options.C: Closed reduction after edema subsides in 20 days
options.D: Closed reduction and swelling will decrease automatically

questions.explanation: Correct Answer D- Closed reduction and swelling will decrease automatically Explanation: In the case of a nasal fracture with no involvement of the septum , the most appropriate approach is to wait for the swelling to subside before proceeding with closed reduction . This period typically lasts around 10-14 days after the trauma, which allows for the edema (swelling) to decrease. After the swelling is reduced, closed reduction can be performed to realign the nasal bones without the risk of additional trauma or incorrect positioning. The reason for this approach is that if the closed reduction is performed too early, the swelling can obstruct proper visualization and alignment of the fractured nasal bones, potentially leading to complications or an incomplete reduction. Nasal Fracture Management : Closed reduction is the preferred management for nasal fractures that involve only the nasal bones, not the septum. Waiting for swelling to decrease naturally allows for better visualization during the procedure, reducing the chances of complications or inadequate realignment. Septo-rhinoplasty is typically only necessary for more complex fractures or when there is significant septal involvement that cannot be corrected with closed reduction. Open reduction is used for more complicated fractures where closed reduction isn't feasible. Incorrect Options: Septo-rhinoplasty (Option A) : is incorrect because it's a more invasive procedure used when there are issues with both the nasal bones and septum. Open reduction (Option B) : is incorrect because open reduction is generally only indicated in cases where closed reduction is not successful or in more complicated fractures. Closed reduction after edema subsides in 20 days (Option C) : is also incorrect because waiting for 20 days is unnecessary. The typical waiting period for swelling to subside is about

questions.question: Identify the fracture in the given diagram:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Chevallet fracture Explanation: A Chevallet fracture runs vertically across the nasal septum. Nasal fractures: Nasal fractures constitute about 40% of all facial fractures and are often accompanied by other facial injuries. Prompt management is crucial to prevent cosmetic and functional deformities. Classification: Nature of Injury: Most fractures result from lateral forces (>66%), with frontal impacts causing fewer injuries. Extent of Deformity: A five-point grading system assesses lateral deviation Grade 0: No deviation Grade 1: Deviation <50% of nose width Grade 2: Deviation 50%-100% of nose width Grade 3: Deviation >100% of nose width Grade 4: Bones almost touching the cheek Pattern of Fracture: Fractures are categorised into three classes based on severity and treatment requirements: Class I (Chevallet Fracture) Class II (Jarjavay Fracture) (Option B) Class III (Naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture) Cause Blows from below Impacts directed from the front High-velocity trauma Fracture Line Vertical fracture from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose. Horizontal fracture starting just above the anterior nasal spine, running backwards just above the junction of septal cartilage and vomer. Involves external buttresses of the nose and ethmoid labyrinth. Pig-like appearance with foreshortened, saddled nose. Clinical Relations: Assess for nasal obstruction and deformity. Significant deformity might only develop later, especially in children. Check for deviation greater than half the width of the nose, which may indicate a septal fracture. Requires reduction of both
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the most frequent location of obstruction caused by a nasal polyp originating from the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Middle meatus Explanation: The most common location for an obstruction caused by a nasal polyp originating from the maxillary sinus is the middle meatus . Nasal polyps are benign growths that arise from the mucosa of the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses. When a polyp forms in the maxillary sinus, it typically expands into the middle meatus, which is the drainage pathway of the maxillary sinus. This can lead to obstruction, sinusitis, or blockage of the sinus drainage. Nasal Polyps : Nasal polyps are non-cancerous growths that develop in the nasal passages or sinuses due to chronic inflammation. They are frequently associated with conditions like chronic rhinosinusitis, asthma, and allergies. The most common location for these polyps is the middle meatus , which is where the maxillary sinuses drain. If the polyps obstruct the drainage system, it can lead to recurrent sinus infections, nasal congestion, and difficulty breathing through the nose. Incorrect Options: Inferior meatus (Option A) : is incorrect because the inferior meatus primarily drains the nasolacrimal duct and not the maxillary sinus, so polyps from the maxillary sinus would not typically obstruct this area. Superior meatus (Option B) : is incorrect because the superior meatus drains the posterior ethmoidal sinuses, not the maxillary sinus, so it would not be the most common site of obstruction for a maxillary sinus polyp. Sphenoethmoidal recess (Option D) : is incorrect because the sphenoethmoidal recess is the drainage site for the sphenoid sinus, not the maxillary sinus, making it an unlikely location for obstruction due to a maxillary sinus polyp. Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery - 6th Edition Page no: 136,137 P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery - 7th Edition Page no: 1332
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the preferred diagnostic procedure prior to performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) CT scan Explanation: The preferred diagnostic procedure prior to performing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) is a CT scan . A CT scan provides detailed imaging of the sinus anatomy and helps to identify any sinus pathology such as sinusitis , nasal polyps , blockages , or anatomical variations that could affect the surgical approach. It is crucial for planning the procedure and avoiding complications during surgery. Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS): FESS is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis, nasal polyps, and other sinus conditions. Before performing this surgery, it is essential to have a clear understanding of the patient's sinus anatomy and any underlying pathology. CT imaging is the gold standard for evaluating the sinuses, as it provides high-resolution, cross-sectional images that allow for precise assessment of sinus structures, mucosal involvement, and any blockages. Incorrect Options: MRI scan (Option A): is incorrect because MRI is typically used for evaluating soft tissue or neurological issues, and it is not as effective as CT for assessing the sinus anatomy and bone structures, which are key for FESS planning. X-ray (Option B): is incorrect because X-ray imaging is less detailed than CT and cannot provide the necessary clarity to evaluate the sinuses thoroughly, especially for complex sinus conditions. Antral lavage (Option C): is incorrect because antral lavage is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used to irrigate the maxillary sinus in cases of chronic sinusitis. However, it is not used for detailed preoperative planning for FESS. A CT scan is the more accurate and comprehensive diagnostic tool for this purpose. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 6th Edition Page no. 419 Scott-Brown’s Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery; 7th Edition Pg 1482-1484
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which is the condition where surgery is done to partially or completely occlude one nostril?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Atrophic rhinitis Explanation: Atrophic rhinitis: Surgery is sometimes performed in atrophic rhinitis to partially or completely occlude one nostril. In this condition, the nasal mucosa becomes thin and atrophic, leading to dry, crusting nasal passages and an impaired mucociliary clearance. Surgical interventions, such as septal surgery or turbinate reduction, may be necessary to manage the symptoms and help prevent further damage to the nasal structures. Atrophic Rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic condition characterized by the thinning and atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It results in symptoms like dry nasal passages, crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, and in some cases, nasal obstruction. In advanced cases, surgical procedures may be done to improve nasal patency or to occlude the nostril to reduce airflow and symptoms. This procedure aims to decrease the discomfort caused by excessive dryness or other symptoms. Vasomotor rhinitis (Option A): is incorrect because vasomotor rhinitis involves nasal congestion triggered by environmental factors, but it does not require surgery to occlude the nostril. Invasive aspergillosis (Option C): is incorrect because invasive aspergillosis is a fungal infection that affects the sinuses and can cause symptoms like nasal obstruction and discharge, but surgery is not typically done to occlude a nostril in this case. Allergic rhinitis (Option D): is incorrect because allergic rhinitis is caused by immune reactions to allergens and is primarily managed with medications like antihistamines or intranasal steroids, not surgery to occlude a nostril. Reference: PL Dhingra Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - 8th Edition • Page no: 178, 179
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following views involves an X-ray beam angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line is also known as?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Water’s view Water’s view: In this radiographic projection, the X-ray beam is angled at approximately 45° to the orbitomeatal line. It is primarily used to visualize the paranasal sinuses, particularly the maxillary sinus, and the facial bones. The patient's head is positioned with the chin raised, and the X-ray beam is directed downward at this 45° angle to obtain clear images of the sinuses and the nasal cavity. Topic sinuses, frontal sinuses, and the nasal cavity. The 45° angulation helps project the sinuses clearly, avoiding superimposition of the surrounding bone structures. This view is often used in diagnosing sinusitis and other sinus-related conditions. Towne’s view (Option B): is incorrect because Towne's view involves a different angulation, typically 30° to the orbitomeatal line, used for visualizing the occipital bone and posterior cranial fossa. Law’s view (Option C): is incorrect because Law’s view is used for temporomandibular joint (TMJ) imaging, where the X-ray beam is angled at 15° to the horizontal plane. Stenver’s view (Option D): is incorrect because Stenver’s view is used for imaging the temporal bone and inner ear, with the X-ray beam directed laterally at an angle to the skull. Reference: P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery - 8th Edition • Page no: 509
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which among the following is not a division of external carotid artery within Kiesselback's plexus?
questions.explanation: ophthalmic artery , which is derived from the internal carotid artery , not the external carotid artery . Therefore, it is not a division of the external carotid artery and does not contribute to Kiesselbach's plexus . Kiesselbach’s Plexus: Kiesselbach's plexus is a vascular network located on the anterior part of the nasal septum , composed of arteries from the external carotid artery . The common arteries involved in Kiesselbach's plexus include: Sphenopalatine artery (from the maxillary artery) Greater palatine artery (from the maxillary artery) Septal branch of the superior labial artery (from the facial artery) These vessels contribute to the blood supply to the nasal septum and are involved in conditions such as epistaxis (nosebleeds) . Incorrect Options: Sphenopalatine artery (Option B): is incorrect because the sphenopalatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery , a branch of the external carotid, and it contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus. Greater palatine artery (Option C): is incorrect because the greater palatine artery is also a branch of the maxillary artery and contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus. Septal branch of superior labial (Option D): is incorrect because the septal branch of the superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery , also part of the external carotid, and contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 8th Edition • Page no: 205
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the first air cell of the anterior ethmoidal sinus called?
questions.explanation: anterior ethmoidal sinus. It is located just beneath the frontal sinus and is often visible on CT scans of the paranasal sinuses. It is situated near the middle turbinate and is a key landmark in the anatomy of the anterior ethmoid region. Agger Nasi: The Agger nasi is the anterior-most ethmoidal air cell and forms part of the anterior ethmoid complex. It is typically seen in sinus imaging, and its location is important in surgical procedures such as functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) . The Agger nasi often drains into the middle meatus and may contribute to sinus congestion when obstructed. Incorrect Options: Bulla ethmoidalis (Option A): is incorrect because the bulla ethmoidalis is a larger air cell in the middle part of the ethmoid sinus, not the first one. Onodi cell (Option B): is incorrect because the Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that lies near the sphenoid sinus, not the anterior ethmoidal cells. Haller cell (Option D): is incorrect because the Haller cell is a variant air cell located in the floor of the orbit and not part of the anterior ethmoidal sinus system. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose & Throat - PL Dhingra - 8th Edition • Page no: 158, 159
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Please identify the structure indicated in the endoscopic image of the right nasal cavity.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Inferior turbinate Explanation: The inferior turbinate is the largest of the three turbinates in the nasal cavity, located along the bottom part of the nasal passages. During endoscopic examination of the right nasal cavity, the inferior turbinate is typically the most prominent structure visible. It plays an important role in conditioning the air we breathe by warming, moistening, and filtering it before it enters the respiratory tract. Inferior Turbinate: The inferior turbinate is composed of bone and covered with mucosa. Its main function is to regulate airflow and humidify the air that enters the nasal passages. It is most commonly involved in conditions like nasal obstruction or rhinitis and may become enlarged due to various inflammatory conditions. Incorrect Options: Middle turbinate (Option B): is incorrect because the middle turbinate is positioned above the inferior turbinate and is typically smaller in size. It is located in the middle meatus and can be visible in endoscopic examinations, but it's not the structure being referred to here. Superior turbinate (Option C): is incorrect because the superior turbinate is the smallest and located towards the top of the nasal cavity. It is not typically the most prominent structure in routine endoscopic views. Uncinate process (Option D): is incorrect because the uncinate process is part of the ethmoid bone and located near the middle meatus. It is often visible in nasal endoscopy but is not as prominent as the inferior turbinate.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the commonly used name for the view shown in the radiograph below, which is used to assess the frontal sinus more effectively?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Caldwell view Explanation: Caldwell view : The Caldwell view is a type of X-ray used to assess the frontal sinuses and is especially useful for evaluating the anterior and posterior ethmoidal sinuses. In this view, the patient’s head is tilted back with the X-ray beam directed at the forehead at a 15° angle. This positioning helps provide a clear view of the frontal sinuses. Caldwell View: The Caldwell view is commonly used in radiology to evaluate the sinuses , especially the frontal sinuses . This projection is typically used for sinus X-rays to assess conditions like sinusitis, fractures, or other abnormalities of the frontal and ethmoid sinuses. Incorrect Options: Water’s view (Option A): is incorrect because the Water’s view is typically used to visualize the maxillary sinuses and is not particularly aimed at frontal sinus evaluation. Pierre’s view (Option C) is incorrect because Pierre’s view is not a standard or widely used radiological term. Towne’s view (Option D): is incorrect because the Towne’s view is used for imaging the skull , particularly for assessing the occipital region and is not

questions.question: A 22-year-old male with recurrent bleeding, presents with bowing of posterior maxillary wall on CECT. All are false except?

options.C: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading blood vessels

questions.explanation: posterior wall of the maxillary sinus is called the Holman-Miller Sign This is seen in Juvenile nasal angiofibroma This tumor bleeds excessively because the tumor lacks smooth muscle that can contract. Examination of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) Anterior Rhinoscopy Reveals a reddish-purple mass obstructing the nasal passages, often with blood-stained discharge. Posterior Rhinoscopy Visualizes a smooth or lobulated mass in the nasopharynx using a small mirror. Oral Examination Assesses for tumor extension into the oral cavity, possibly pushing the soft palate downwards. Neck Palpation Detects any enlarged lymph nodes, especially in the upper cervical region. Neurological Examination Assesses cranial nerve involvement, focusing on eye movements, facial sensation, and hearing. Digital palpation Caution, avoid digital palpation of the nasopharyngeal mass to prevent severe bleeding. Investigations of Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan Investigation of choice ; shows tumor size, location, and bony involvement. Pathognomonic sign: Holman-Miller sign (bowing of maxillary wall). Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Evaluates soft tissue and intracranial extension, differentiates between extradural and intradural spread. (Option A ruled out) Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) Visualizes tumor vascularity, identifies feeding vessels and aids in preoperative embolization to reduce surgical blood loss. Nasopharyngoscopy Provides a direct view of the tumor, but biopsy is generally avoided due to high bleeding risk. (Option C ruled out) Audiometry Assesses hearing loss caused by Eustachian tube obstruction; establishes baseline and monitors post-treatment hearing. Biopsy Biopsy is contraindicated due to risk of profuse bleeding. Incorrect Options: Outgrown the blood supply (Option A): Outgrown the blood supply is a wrong statement because JNA is an extremely vascular tumor. Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels (Option C): JNA has its blood supply which is most commonly by the internal maxillary artery. It lacks capsule (Option D): Capsule is associated with the extension of the tumor and not bleeding. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 250
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which structure does the anterior ethmoidal sinus drain into?
questions.explanation: meatus. Anterior ethmoidal sinus: Aspect Details Definition Air-filled cavities within the ethmoid bone Part of the ethmoidal sinus system Location Between the nasal cavity and the orbit Anterior group of ethmoidal air cells (compared to middle/posterior groups) Drainage Pathway Drains into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity via the infundibulum and hiatus semilunaris Innervation Supplied by the anterior ethmoidal nerve , a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from CN V1 – ophthalmic division) Blood Supply Anterior ethmoidal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery ) Clinical Relevance Can be involved in sinusitis (especially if drainage is blocked) Close to orbit and anterior cranial fossa — risk of orbital cellulitis or intracranial spread if infected Incorrect Options: Options B, C & D: The anterior ethmoidal sinus does not drain in these sinuses. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 279
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the name of the staging system used for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma?
questions.explanation: Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma: I A Involvement limited to the nose or naso-pharynx I B Extension into one or more sinuses II A Minimal extension into pterygopalatine fossa II B Occupies the entire pterygopalatine fossa with or without erosion of the orbital IIII II C Involvement of the infratemporal fossa with or without extension to the cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates III A Erosion of the skull base (the middle cranial fossa/base of the pterygoids), minimal intracranial extension III B Erosion of the skull base, extensive intracranial extension with or without cavernous sinus invasion Incorrect Options: Option B -TNM staging: TNM staging is not used for Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma Option C - Ann Arbor staging system: Ann Arbor staging system is used for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Option D - Dukes criteria: Dukes criteria is used for Infective endocarditis. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 153
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which structure is most commonly involved in the compression of the anterior ethmoid nerve, leading to Sluder's neuralgia?
questions.explanation: is the most commonly involved structure in the compression of the anterior ethmoid nerve leading to anterior ethmoid neuralgia (Sluder's neuralgia). Incorrect Options: Options A, C & D: Superior turbinate, inferior turbinate, and nasal septum are not the most commonly involved structures in the compression of anterior ethmoid nerve Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 154

questions.question: What is the preferred initial management for a patient presenting with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea?

options.C: Bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities
options.D: Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management

questions.explanation: The initial management for CSF Rhinorrhea is bed rest with head elevation and avoidance of straining activities. It also includes administration of antibiotics and diuretics. Treatment of CSF Rhinorrhea Conservative Management: Bed rest, head elevation Stool softeners, avoidance of nose blowing, sneezing, and straining. Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent meningitis Acetazolamide to decrease CSF formation Lumbar drain if indicated Surgical Repair Approaches: Neurosurgical Intracranial Approach Extradural Approaches (rarely used): External ethmoidectomy (cribriform plate/ethmoid area) Transseptal sphenoidal approach Osteoplastic flap (frontal sinus leaks) Transnasal Endoscopic Approach (preferred for anterior cranial fossa and sphenoid sinus): Site identification (e.g., cribriform plate, sphenoid, ethmoid roof) Grafting with fascia, and cartilage for large defects (>2 cm), followed by mucosa placement Use of Surgicel and Gelfoam to further strengthen the area. High-antibiotic nasal packing Lumbar drain for high CSF pressure Frontal Sinus Leaks: May require osteoplastic flap and sinus obliteration with fat. Incorrect Options: FESS (Option A): FESS is not used in the initial management for a patient with CSF Rhinorrhoea. Administration of steroids (Option B): Administration of steroids is not preferred in the management of CSF Rhinorrhoea. Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management (Option D): Immediate surgical repair without initial medical management is not preferred in management of CSF Rhinorrhea. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 153
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Identify the most common location of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:
questions.explanation: Fossa of Rosenmuller. The area marked as number 2 indicates the Fossa of Rosenmuller. Aspect Details Definition • A deep recess located in the nasopharynx , behind the torus tubarius (the cartilaginous opening of the Eustachian tube) Location • Posterolateral wall of the nasopharynx • Just behind the Eustachian tube opening Clinical Importance • Common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) origin • Close to the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube , so tumors here may cause ear symptoms Related Structures • Close to the Eustachian tube , tensor and levator veli palatini muscles , and retropharyngeal lymph nodes Symptoms if Involved • Unilateral ear blockage or hearing loss (due to Eustachian tube obstruction) • Nasal obstruction , epistaxis (nosebleeds) • Neck mass (from lymph node spread) Incorrect Options: Options A) Involvement of the superior nasopharynx (1) is uncommon but may lead to early skull base invasion and cranial nerve involvement . Option C) Posterior nasopharynx (3): This site is less frequently affected compared to the lateral walls but may be involved in advanced cases. Option D) This location is rare, but tumors here may cause early nasal symptoms such as epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and sinus involvement

questions.question: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?
questions.explanation: These are triangular folds in the nasal corner of the upper eyelids due to the changes in the tone of the corrugator and zygomatic facial muscles. Incorrect Options: Option A - Allergic shiners: Allergic shiners are dark circles under the eye which is a sign of allergic rhinitis. Option B - Allergic salute: The patient keeps rubbing the nose in an upward direction, resembling a salute which is a sign of allergic rhinitis. Option D - Denis morgan lines: Denis morgan lines is a fold or line in the skin below the lower eyelid which is also a sign of allergic rhinitis Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following is the most commonly affected nerve after parotid surgery?
questions.explanation: parotid surgery as it traverses perpendicularly through the parotid gland. The cervical branch of facial nerve is involved in this It leads to Bell's palsy Incorrect Options: Option B, C, and D: Though they supply the parotid gland, they are not commonly injured Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 153
