questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and a history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation: along with right-sided serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy which helps in the diagnosis of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Clinical features: Nasal Obstruction Discharge Denasal speech (rhinolalia clausa) Epistaxis Otologic Conductive hearing loss Serous or suppurative otitis media (Unilateral serous otitis media in adults is an important indicator) Tinnitus Dizziness due to Eustachian tube obstruction Ophthalmoneurologic Squint Diplopia (CN VI involvement) Ophthalmoplegia (CN III, IV, VI) Facial pain Reduced corneal reflex (CN V involvement) Exophthalmos Blindness (CN II) Jugular foramen syndrome with CN IX, X, and XI involvement Horner syndrome Cervical Nodal Metastases Lump of nodes between the angle of the jaw and mastoid, or along the spinal accessory in the posterior triangle Distant Metastases Common sites-bone, lung, and liver Common symptoms Cervical lymphadenopathy Hearing loss Nasal obstruction Epistaxis Cranial nerve palsies (CN VI most common) Headache Earache Neck pain Weight loss Incorrect Options: Angiofibroma (Option A): Angiofibroma is seen in the juvenile age group which eliminates the option. Adenoid hypertrophy (Option C): Adenoid hypertrophy is not associated with cervical lymphadenopathy Tonsillar abscess (Option D): This is an infection and not tumor to be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 250
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A fracture has occurred at the cribriform plate area of the ethmoid bone. The patient can present with which symptom?
questions.explanation: trauma, and the most common site of CSF leak (CSF Rhinorrhoea) is the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, which is the weakest part of the bone. Common Sites of CSF Rhinorrhea Anterior cranial fossa Middle cranial fossa Temporal bone fracture Cribriform plate(most common) Roof of ethmoid air cells Frontal sinus Sphenoid sinus(following trauma) CSF reaches the middle ear, escaping through the eustachian tube into the nose(CSF otorhinorrhea) Aetiology Trauma (Most common): Accidental or surgical (e.g., sinus surgery, nasal polypectomy, skull base surgery). Inflammations: Mucocoeles, fungal infections, osteomyelitis, sinus polyposis. Neoplasms: Benign and malignant tumours invading the skull base. Congenital: Meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, gliomas with skull base defects. Idiopathic: Spontaneous leaks with no known cause. Investigations for CSF Rhinorrhea Handkerchief test (Halo sign): Simple bedside test; CSF forms clear halo around blood spot. Beta-2 transferrin: Gold standard biochemical test; highly specific for CSF. High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Identifies bony defects in skull base. CT Cisternography: Contrast-enhanced; precise localization of active CSF leaks. MRI Cisternography: Non-invasive; useful for identifying meningoceles/encephaloceles. Fluorescein Test: Intrathecal dye injection; helps in intraoperative leak localization. Incorrect Options: Options A, B & D: Hearing loss, visual loss, and diplopia are not the symptoms of trauma (fracture) to the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 153
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Type of voice associated with the hypertrophied adenoids?
questions.explanation: obstruction to the nasal airway. This further causes nasal twang in the voice which is called Rhinorrhea clausa Incorrect Options: Rhinolalia aperta (Option B) : This happens due to elevated resonance in the voice due to increased aeration which occurs in velopharyngeal insufficiency or palatal paralysis. Hot potato voice (Option C) : This feature is seen when there is tonsilar hypertrophy or abscess. Hypernasality (Option D): This is Rhinolalia aperta and can be eliminated by the explanation of the above option B Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 253
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A patient presents with a foul smell from the nose, anosmia, and nasal obstruction. The following is noted during examination. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: cavity The patient has anosmia beacuse the his olfactory fibres are atrophic-merciful anosmia The people around the patient complain of foul smell where the patient is unaware of this. Hence called as merciful anosmia. All these are features of atrophic rhinitis: Primarily affects females, starts around puberty Foul-smelling nasal discharge; patients are usually unaware of it themselves and have anosmia (merciful anosmia). Paradoxical nasal obstruction despite enlarged nasal chambers. Epistaxis from crust removal. Pale nasal mucosa, atrophied turbinates, potential septal perforation, nasal vestibule dermatitis, saddle nose deformity. Possible extension to pharynx and larynx leading to atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis. Eustachian tube obstruction and middle ear effusion cause hearing impairment. Incorrect Options: Rhinitis sicca (Option B): Exposure to dry/hot climates (typically seen in people working in bakeries). The crusting is limited to only anterior I of the nose and there is no associated anosmia in this case. Rhinitis medicamentosa (Option C): This is due to abuse of alpha adrenergic agonist like xylometazoline which cause nasal obstruction and discharge Allergic rhinitis (Option D): There is serum IgE involved , which causes profuse nasal discharge but not crusting. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 253
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A patient was presented to the OPD with complaints of greenish black matter in the nose with merciful smelling. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: turbinates, and underlying bones , leading to the formation of foul-smelling nasal crusts . The patient presents with greenish-black nasal crusts and a merciful (foul) smell , which is characteristic of ozena (a term for atrophic rhinitis with a fetid odor). Primary Atrophic Rhinitis: Aspect Details Causes Heredity Endocrine disturbance Racial factors Nutritional deficiency Infective: Klebsiella ozaenae Autoimmune Clinical Features And Examination findings Primarily affects females, starts around puberty Foul-smelling nasal discharge; patients are usually unaware of it themselves and have anosmia (merciful anosmia). Paradoxical nasal obstruction despite enlarged nasal chambers. Epistaxis from crust removal. Pale nasal mucosa, atrophied turbinates, potential septal perforation, nasal vestibule dermatitis, saddle nose deformity. Possible extension to pharynx and larynx leading to atrophic pharyngitis and laryngitis. Eustachian tube obstruction and middle ear effusion cause hearing impairment. Other Options: Allergic Rhinitis (Option A) : Presents with watery rhinorrhea, sneezing, nasal congestion, and itching but not with foul-smelling crusts . Rhinitis Caseosa ( Option C) : Characterized by caseous (cheese-like) nasal secretions , often seen in chronic fungal or bacterial infections , but not typically with greenish-black crusts . Rhinitis Sicca (Option D) : Involves dryness of the nasal mucosa due to environmental factors but lacks foul-smelling crust formation . Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 654
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is shown in the image below (circled)?
questions.explanation: where the drainage pathways of the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses converge. It plays a crucial role in sinus ventilation and drainage . It is the common drainage pathway for the anterior ethmoid, maxillary, and frontal sinuses into the middle meatus . Obstruction of the OMC can lead to chronic rhinosinusitis . It is an important region in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) . Other Options: Columella (Option A) : The fleshy, midline structure that separates the nostrils . Nasal Valve (Option C) : The narrowest part of the nasal airway , important for regulating airflow. Crest of Maxilla (Option D) : A bony ridge on the maxilla where the nasal septum attaches . Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pg 435
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A South Indian male farmer presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of reddish mass coming out from the nose and histopathology image as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: includes the presence of reddish or pinkish masses or polyps in the nasal cavity and histopathology shows sporangium with sporangiospores as seen in the images shown. Rhinosporidiosis: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protistan protozoa- Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is a water-borne disease- contaminated water of ponds usually with cow dung. Epidemiology: Common in India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan More common in southern states than in northern India Life cycle: Trophic stage → Development of sporangium → Release of endospores Clinical Features: Blood-tinged nasal discharge Nasal block Epistaxis Leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple colored mass attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall. Very vascular mass and bleeds easily on touch. White dots are studded on its surface representing the sporangia. Incorrect Options: Rhinoscleroma (Option B): Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It is characterized by the formation of fibrotic nodules in the nose and other respiratory passages as shown below. Histopathology shows Miculicz cells (large foam cells with central nucleus and cytoplasm with the bacilli) and Russell bodies (cells with eccentric nucleus and eosinophilic cytoplasm). Rhinophyma (Option C): Rhinophyma is a condition characterized by progressive enlargement of the nose due to sebaceous gland hyperplasia as shown below. It is typically associated with acne rosacea. Nasal polyp (Option D): Nasal polyps are non-cancerous growths that develop in the lining of the nose or sinuses. They are usually soft, painless, and non-inflammatory translucent tissue containing mucus unlike the fleshy polyps of rhinosporidiosis. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 236
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What lies posterior to the marked structure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Eustachian tube Explanation: The marked structure is the inferior turbinate. The structure located approximately 1.25 cm posterior to the inferior turbinate is the opening of the Eustachian tube. Important Structures in the Nasopharynx Related to the Lateral Wall of the Nose: Lateral Wall Continuation: The lateral wall of the nose extends beyond the turbinates into the lateral wall of the nasopharynx. Eustachian Tube (ET): Located 1.25 cm posterior and slightly inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. Mnemonic: Behind the Inferior turbinate is ET (E for Inferior). Sphenopalatine Foramen: (Option C) Located 1 cm posterior and slightly inferior to the posterior end of the middle turbinate. Connects the nasopharynx laterally with the sphenopalatine (pterygopalatine) fossa. Odontoid (Option A): The odontoid process (dens) is part of the C2 vertebra in the cervical spine and is unrelated to nasal or nasopharyngeal structures. Agger nasi (Option D): The agger nasi is an anterior ethmoidal air cell, located anterior to the middle turbinate, not posterior to the inferior turbinate. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10232923/
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 45-year-old male was admitted with respiratory distress. CT showed a nasal polyp with fluid collection in the sinus. Drainage of which of the following is obstructed?
questions.explanation: When a nasal polyp is present, it can obstruct this drainage pathway, leading to fluid accumulation in the maxillary sinus, as seen on CT. The maxillary sinus or the Antrum of Highmore , is the largest of the paranasal sinuses, occupying the body of the maxilla. Shape - Pyramidal Size - 15mL Base - toward the lateral wall of the nose Apex - extends into the zygomatic process of the maxillary bone Relations: Anterior wall: Formed by the facial surface of the maxilla. Posterior wall: Anterior surface of pterygopalatine fossa. Medial wall: Thin and membranous in some areas, this wall borders the middle and inferior meatuses and separates the maxillary sinus from the nasal cavity. Roof: Formed by the floor of the orbit Floor: Located approximately 1 cm below the floor of the nasal cavity, it is formed by the alveolar and palatine processes of the maxilla. Closely related to the roots of the second premolar and first molar teeth. Cavities in these teeth are associated with oro antral fistula. Arterial supply: Branches of the maxillary artery, specifically the infraorbital artery, greater palatine artery, and the posterior superior alveolar artery. Venous drainage: Pterygoid venous plexus and the facial vein. Lymphatic drainage: Submandibular lymph nodes. Nerve supply: Infraorbital nerve, greater palatine nerve, and the posterior superior alveolar nerve, which are branches of the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2). Other Options: Ethmoidal Sinus (Option A) : Drains into the middle meatus (anterior ethmoids) or superior meatus (posterior ethmoids) ; obstruction causes ethmoid sinusitis. Sphenoidal Sinus (Option B): Drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess ; obstruction leads to sphenoid sinusitis, often with deep headaches. Frontal Sinus (Option C): Drains into
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is the least probable cause of mucormycosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Broad spectrum antibiotics Explanation: Mucormycosis is caused by molds, mainly Rhizopus. Neutropenia, uncontrolled diabetes without DKA, and prolonged use of steroids are all risk factors for developing mucormycosis. However, broad-spectrum antibiotics are not directly associated with the development of mucormycosis. Risk Factors for Mucormycosis: Diabetes Mellitus : (Option C) Uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) – the most significant metabolic risk factor. Immunosuppression : High-dose steroids (e.g., in COVID-19 or autoimmune conditions). (Option D) Organ transplantation (e.g., liver, kidney) and immunosuppressive medications: Azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus, cyclosporine . HIV/AIDS – advanced disease with low CD4 count. Neutropenia : (Option A) Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) < 1500 . Common in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. Iron Overload : Use of Deferoxamine or other iron-chelating agents. Mechanical Ventilation : Prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of fungal infections. Autoimmune Disorders : Diseases requiring immunosuppressive therapy. Other Causes : Malnutrition. Trauma or burns. Prolonged antibiotic use (disrupts normal flora). Reference: https://www.cdc.gov/murcomycosis/risk-factors/index.html#:~:text=
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman takes aspirin for a headache, later presented with wheezing and breathlessness. Along with these two symptoms, what other clinical findings are likely to be found in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Nasal polyp Explanation: The woman likely developed aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), which is also known as Samter's triad. Samter's Triad includes asthma, sinusitis with recurrent nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs. Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD) : also known as Samter's Triad, is a chronic medical condition characterized by the triad of asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and hypersensitivity reactions to aspirin and other(NSAIDs). Symptoms: The symptoms of AERD can vary in severity and may include: Recurrent episodes of asthma Chronic rhinosinusitis Nasal polyps, which are small growths in the lining of the nose that can obstruct the airway and cause breathing difficulties Hypersensitivity reactions to aspirin and other NSAIDs, which can cause severe respiratory symptoms, hives, swelling, and even anaphylaxis. Eosinophilia (Option A): Eosinophilia is a feature of allergic conditions but is not significantly associated with AERD. Extrinsic asthma (Option C): In Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), the asthma component is considered a type of non-allergic or intrinsic asthma rather than extrinsic asthma. Drug interaction (Option D): NSAIDs can worsen asthma symptoms in patients with the condition, but there is no drug-drug interaction causing AERD. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5951071/
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is true about inverted papilloma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Benign and invasive Explanation: Inverted papilloma is the most common benign tumor of the nasal cavity. Although it is a benign tumor, it is locally invasive. It has a high rate of recurrence. The tumor grows inward from the lining of the nose and sinuses and can invade the underlying bone and surrounding structures, hence the term "inverted." Inverted papilloma: is a benign tumor arising from the nasal epithelium, often associated with the paranasal sinuses, particularly the maxillary sinus. It typically presents in older adults and is more common in males. Risk Factors: The history of smoking is a notable risk factor for the development of inverted papilloma Clinical Presentation: The patient presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a sensation of pressure, which are common symptoms associated with inverted papilloma. Examination : The presence of a fleshy, lobulated mass on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity is characteristic of inverted papilloma. Histopathology: Invagination of the superficial epithelium into the underlying stroma. The epithelium may be of the keratinized squamous, respiratory or transitional types which may coexist in varying proportions.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with a headache and thick nasal discharge, and upon examination, shows hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate with a mulberry appearance?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypertrophic rhinitis Explanation: Hypertrophic rhinitis is a chronic condition characterized by inflammation and thickening of the nasal mucosa, often due to prolonged irritation (e.g., allergies, infection, or pollutants). The mulberry appearance of the inferior turbinate is a hallmark of hypertrophic rhinitis, caused by nodular swellings on the turbinates. Symptoms like headache and thick nasal discharge are common due to nasal obstruction and secondary infections. Hypertrophic Rhinitis Cause : Progression from untreated chronic simple rhinitis, leading to repeated infections and submucosal fibrosis , causing turbinate hypertrophy. Commonly Affected Turbinate : Inferior turbinate – develops a mulberry appearance . Primary Symptom : Nasal obstruction (due to fibrosis). Management : Nasal obstruction due to fibrosis requires turbinate size reduction via partial or total turbinectomy. Turbinectomy (partial or total): To reduce the size of hypertrophied turbinates. Methods include: Laser surgery. Cryosurgery. Diathermy. Radiofrequency ablation. Surgical submucous resection of turbinate. Atrophic rhinitis (Option A): is a condition in which the nasal mucosa thins and dries out, leading to foul-smelling nasal discharge, crusting, and obstruction. The symptoms are not consistent with those seen in the patient. Common cold (Option B): Is a viral infection that affects the upper respiratory tract. It typically presents with symptoms such as cough, runny nose, and sore throat. Nasal polyp (Option D): are benign growths that arise from the lining of the nose or sinuses. They can lead to symptoms such as nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, and reduced sense of smell. While they may cause nasal discharge, the mulberry appearance of the inferior turbinate is not a feature of nasal polyps. Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2468548821000345
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: An elderly diabetic female patient is presented, as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Mucormycosis Explanation: The image, coupled with the clinical context of an elderly diabetic female, strongly suggests Mucormycosis as the most probable diagnosis. The image shows black necrotic tissue near the orbit, which is characteristic of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis . Mucormycosis It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen Rhizopus Absidia Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained) Pathogenesis Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction. Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness) Common Sites Rhinocerebral Form : Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients. Pulmonary Infections : When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications. Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis Clinical Features Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis : Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black ), fever, and mucosal necrosis . Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms. Pulmonary Zygomycosis : Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis Diagnosis Histological Examination : Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae. Culture: After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old male who has nonaxial proptosis in his left eye and a history of a road traffic accident 15 years ago, as suggested by the provided CT image?
questions.explanation: of a sinus cavity becomes inflamed or blocked. When a mucocele forms in the frontal sinus, it can cause proptosis (bulging) of the eye. This commonly occurs as a result of obstruction to the frontal ostium due to chronic disease of the frontal recess or due to postsurgical/ traumatic fibrosis causing blockage. Symptoms of a frontal mucocele include: Proptosis (bulging) of the eye Headache or facial pain Vision changes or double vision Nasal congestion or discharge Sinus pressure or pain Swelling or tenderness in the forehead Incorrect Options: Frontal meningioma (Option B): A meningioma is a tumor that arises from the lining of the brain or spinal cord. When a meningioma forms in the front of the head, it can cause eye proptosis. However, meningiomas are relatively uncommon in young adults, and a history of trauma may not be associated with developing a meningioma. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option C): Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare and benign tumor, typically in adolescent males. It arises from the back of the nose or upper throat and can cause eye proptosis as it grows. However, the history of trauma 15 years prior is not usually associated with developing a juvenile
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from nose, nasal obstruction, and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination what will be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.explanation: obstruction, and red polyploidal mass) is suggestive of Rhinosporidiosis, as on histopathology there are sporangia with spores. Rhinosporidiosis: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by an aquatic protistan protozoa- Rhinosporidium seeberi. It is a water-borne disease- contaminated water of ponds usually with cow dung. Epidemiology: Common in India, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan More common in southern states than in northern India Life cycle: Trophic stage → Development of sporangium → Release of endospores Clinical Features: Blood-tinged nasal discharge Nasal block Epistaxis Leafy, polypoidal, pink to purple colored mass attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall. Very vascular mass and bleeds easily on touch. White dots are studded on its surface representing the sporangia. Incorrect Options: Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option B): This option is incorrect as basal cell carcinoma exhibits the findings given below. Rhinoscleroma (Option C) : This is incorrect as Rhinoscleroma presents with nasal obstruction, erythematous granular or nodular swellings, crusts on the swellings, and swelling of the lips and gums. Lupus Vulgaris (Option D): This option is incorrect as Lupus vulgaris (also known as tuberculosis luposa) are painful cutaneous tuberculosis skin lesions with nodular appearance, most often on the face around the nose, eyelids, lips, cheeks, ears, and neck. Reference: Diseases of the Ear, Nose, and Throat, PL Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page no: 153
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 30-year-old women present with upper respiratory tract infection and orbital pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: proptosis visible on the CT and the patient is also having orbital pain. Orbital Cellulitis Definition Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum. Etiology Exogenous Infection : Occurs due to penetrating injuries. Example: foreign body retention, surgical procedures like evisceration, enucleation, orbitotomy, dacryocystectomy. Endogenous Infection : From metastatic infections. Example: breast abscess, puerperal sepsis, thrombophlebitis, septicemia Extension from Neighboring Structures (most common) : Paranasal sinuses (most common: ethmoid sinus) , teeth, face, eyelids, intracranial cavity, and intraorbital structures. Clinical Features Symptoms : Swelling and severe pain (worsened by eye movement or pressure). Systemic symptoms: fever, nausea, vomiting, prostration. Vision loss and/or diplopia in moderate to advanced cases. Signs : Swelling of lids with woody hardness and redness. Chemosis (conjunctival swelling), which may lead to necrosis. Axial proptosis. Restricted eye movements. RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) may occur due to optic neuropathy or central retinal artery occlusion. Fundus examination may show retinal vein congestion, papillitis, or papilledema Staging Modified Chandler staging system: Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to orbital septum) Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum) Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess Stage IV: Orbital abscess Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis Investigations Cultures : Nasal, conjunctival, and blood samples for bacterial culture. Complete Blood Count : Leukocytosis. X-ray PNS : To detect sinusitis. Orbital Ultrasonography : To detect orbital abscesses. CT Scan/MRI : Differentiates preseptal from postseptal cellulitis, detects abscesses, intracranial extension, and guides surgical drainage. Incorrect Options: Sinusitis (Option B): This option is incorrect as proptosis is visible on imaging. Both A and B (Option C): This option is also incorrect. Periosteal abscess (Option D): This option is incorrect as CT findings of periosteal abscess show abscess behind the orbit.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 54-year-old male presented with nasal obstruction. On examination there was an irregular mass protruding from the choanae. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation: in the maxillary sinus (antrum) and extends into the nasal cavity, passing through the choanae (the openings at the back of the nasal cavity that lead to the throat). These polyps are typically unilateral and can cause nasal obstruction, especially if they protrude significantly into the nasal cavity. Incorrect Options: Option A - Thornwaldt Cyst: A Thornwaldt cyst (also known as nasopharyngeal cyst or pharyngeal bursitis) is a cyst that forms in the nasopharynx. However, it is usually not associated with an irregular mass protruding from the choanae. It might cause nasal symptoms, but it's less likely to present with the specific characteristics described in the scenario. Option C - Hypertrophic Rhinitis: Hypertrophic rhinitis refers to the enlargement of the nasal turbinates due to chronic inflammation. While it can lead to nasal obstruction, it doesn't usually manifest as an irregular mass protruding from the choanae. It's more associated with internal nasal structures rather than external protrusions. Option D - Adenoid Hypertrophy: Adenoid hypertrophy involves the enlargement of the adenoid tissue, which is in the back of the nasal cavity, near the choanae. However, adenoids don't typically present as an irregular mass protruding through the choanae. Instead, they might cause more generalized nasal obstruction and related symptoms.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 40-year-old patient presenting with non-caseating granulomas and a saddle nose perforation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: of non-caseating granulomas and saddle nose perforation strongly points towards Wegener's granulomatosis (now often referred to as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis), making option C the most likely diagnosis in this case. Incorrect Options: Option A - TB (Tuberculosis): While TB can also cause granulomas, the presentation of saddle nose perforation is not typically associated with TB. TB commonly affects the lungs and can cause symptoms like cough, fever, and weight loss. Option B - Leprosy: Leprosy can cause granulomas as well, but saddle nose perforation is not a common feature of leprosy. Leprosy usually affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, leading to skin lesions and nerve damage. Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis can cause granulomas as part of its secondary stage manifestations, but saddle nose perforation is not a prominent characteristic of syphilis. Syphilis typically causes a variety of symptoms including skin rash, fever, and mucous membrane lesions. Reference: .
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A infant developed difficulty in breathing. His symptoms improve with crying. In which disease, symptoms get improve with crying?
questions.explanation: blockage or narrowing of the back of the nasal passage (choanae) that leads from the nasal cavity to the throat. This blockage can make it difficult for an infant to breathe through their nose. Interestingly, infants with choanal atresia often improve their breathing when they cry. When they cry, they open their mouths wider, allowing more air to flow into their lungs through their mouth, bypassing the blocked nasal passages. This temporary improvement in breathing during crying is a characteristic feature of choanal atresia. Incorrect Options: Option A - Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thinning and inflammation of the nasal mucosa, leading to symptoms like nasal crusting, foul odor, and nasal congestion. Crying is unlikely to significantly improve symptoms in atrophic rhinitis. Option B - Acute rhinosinusitis: Acute rhinosinusitis is an inflammation of the nasal and sinus passages, often caused by infections. While crying might lead to temporary relief of symptoms due to increased nasal secretions, it's not a defining characteristic of this condition. Option C - Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is an allergic reaction that leads to symptoms like sneezing, itching, runny or stuffy nose. Crying might temporarily relieve some symptoms, but it's not a specific feature of allergic rhinitis.
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Water’s view best visualizes which of the following sinuses?
questions.explanation: visualize the maxillary sinus. The Waters view primarily visualizes the frontal sinuses, ethmoid sinuses, and maxillary sinuses. (Maxillary sinus is best visualized) It is done in the chin-up position. If done with open mouth (allowing for better visualization of the sphenoid sinuses) it is called Pierre's view. Incorrect Options: Options B, C and D are not best visualized by Water’s view as explained above. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the technique shown in the provided image?
questions.explanation: control epistaxis. This method involves the application of digital pressure over Kisselbach's plexus and bends forward for at least 15-20 minutes Incorrect Options: Option A - Epley's maneuver: Epley's maneuver is a therapeutic technique used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). It involves a series of head and body movements to reposition displaced otoconia (calcium crystals) within the inner ear, specifically the posterior semicircular canal. Option C - McGovern's technique: McGovern's technique is used in choanal atresia. feeding a nipple with a large hole helps in the oral airway and provides good oral airways Option D - Valsalva maneuver : The Valsalva maneuver is a physiological maneuver that involves forced expiration against a closed airway. It is commonly used to assess and evaluate the function of the middle ear and Eustachian tube, as well as to induce or relieve pressure in the ears. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the most frequently reported symptom in patients with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma?
questions.explanation: cervical lymphadenopathy as an early sign. The most common lymph node involved is LN between the angle of the jaw and mastoid and LN along the spinal accessory and in the posterior triangle of the neck in HO's triangle. Incorrect Options: Option B - Hearing Loss: While conductive hearing loss can occur in patients with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma, it is not the most frequently reported symptom. Hearing loss is more commonly associated with conditions affecting the middle or inner ear rather than nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Option C - Airway Obstruction: Airway obstruction can occur in advanced cases of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not typically the most frequently reported symptom. Option D - Epistaxis: Epistaxis, or nosebleeds, can be a symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most frequently reported symptom. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Pott’s puffy tumor ?
questions.explanation: abscess of the frontal bone. Pott's puffy tumor is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis that involves the spread of infection from the frontal sinus to the overlying frontal bone. Pott's puffy tumor refers to a subperiosteal abscess that develops on the frontal bone as a result of the spread of infection from the frontal sinus. It is characterized by localized swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the forehead. Incorrect Options: Options B, C and D are incorrect and the correct option is explained above . Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Mickulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristically observed in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: in rhinoscleroma. It is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, a gram-negative bacillus. Mikulicz cells are vacuolated histiocytes. Russell bodies are eosinophilic inclusions in plasma cells. Incorrect Options Options B, C and D are not characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication for Young's operation?
questions.explanation: Young's modification , is a surgical procedure performed for atrophic rhinitis . Here mucosal flaps are elevated to close the nasal cavity . Incorrect Options Options B, C and D are not indications for Young's operation. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which could be the probable stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
questions.explanation: nasopharynx exclusively seen in juvenile age group. It is the most common tumor of the nasopharynx and is exclusively seen in males. According to Radkowski's staging system: Stage IA: The tumor is limited to the nose and nasopharyngeal area, without extension beyond this region. Stage IB: The tumor extends into one or more sinuses. Stage IIA: There is minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa Stage IIB: The tumor occupies the pterygopalatine fossa, with or without erosion of the orbital structures. Stage IIC: The tumor extends into the infratemporal fossa, with or without involvement of the cheek or pterygoid plate. Stage IIIA: There is erosion of the skull base, specifically involving the middle cranial fossa or pterygoid plates. Stage IIIB: The tumor has eroded the skull base with intracranial extension, with or without involvement of the cavernous sinus. Incorrect Options: Options A, C and D are incorrect as explained above. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: How would you describe a fracture of the nasal septum that occurs both vertically and horizontally?
questions.explanation: septum is a Jarjaway fracture, this is nearly always due to lateral trauma , while one running vertically is known as a Chevallet Fracture, this is usually caused by a frontal or fronto-lateral blow. Incorrect Options: Option B - Parade ground fracture : It is a mandibular fracture involving bilateral subcondylar fractures of the condylar processes Option C - Tripod Fracture: A tripod fracture, also known as a zygomaticomaxillary complex fracture, involves fractures of the zygomatic arch, orbital floor, and maxillary sinus and forms a "tripod" shape. Option D - None of the above: This option is not correc t Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Nasopharyngeal chordoma arises from which of the following?
questions.explanation: remnants of the notochord. Patients usually present with complaints of headache and cranial nerve palsies due to intracranial spread, nasal obstruction with discharge, epistaxis, and dysphagia in those with pharyngeal spread. Slow growth rate of the tumor, which gradually fills the nasopharyngeal cavity leads to delayed oncological diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option A - Pharyngeal bursa: Pharyngeal bursa is located in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass. PHARYNGEAL BURSITIS is an infection of the pharyngeal bursa which is a median recess representing attachment of notochord to endoderm of the primitive pharynx. Option C - Rathke's pouch: It is represented clinically by a dimple above the adenoids and is reminiscent of the buccal mucosal invagination, to form the anterior lobe of pituitary. A craniopharyngioma may arise from it. Option D - Luschka's bursa: Pouch of Luschka: During development, notochord is attached to the endoderm in the area of nasopharynx producing an invagination pouch. Persistence of this pouch causes Thornwaldt's cyst which may get infected to form an abscess. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the most frequently observed symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: lymphadenopathy (neck swelling) as an early sign. The most common lymph node involved is LN between the angle of the jaw and mastoid and LN along the spinal accessory and in the posterior triangle of the neck in HO's triangle. Incorrect Options: Option A - Airway obstruction: This symptom can occur in advanced stages of nasopharyngeal carcinoma when the tumor grows and blocks the nasal passages or affects the surrounding structures. Option B - Headache: Headaches are a non-specific symptom While headaches can occur in some cases of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, they are not a common or specific symptom. Option D - Epistaxis: While nasopharyngeal carcinoma can sometimes cause epistaxis, it is not a prominent or common symptom. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in case of continuous watery discharge from the nose following a trauma?
questions.explanation: fluid from the nose. It can be a result of trauma to the head or skull fracture. Continuous watery discharge from the nose after trauma is a characteristic feature of CSF rhinorrhea. Incorrect Options: Option A - CSF otorrhea: CSF otorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the ear. Option B - Common colds: Common colds typically present with symptoms such as nasal congestion, runny nose, sneezing, and a clear or slightly colored discharge. Option D - Anterior epistaxis : Anterior epistaxis refers to nosebleeds that occur from the front part of the nose. It typically presents with bleeding from the nasal cavity and may cause a discharge of blood. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes a patient who is unable to smell coffee but can smell ammonia after experiencing head trauma?

options.A: Ammonia is used for testing olfactory nerve
options.B: The olfaction system is not damaged

questions.explanation: with the mucous membranes lining the nasal passages, it can trigger a sensation of irritation or burning, which is detected by nerve endings associated with the trigeminal nerve, which is responsible for sensations such as pain, temperature, and chemical irritants. When a person smells ammonia, the trigeminal nerve can be activated, leading to a sensation or perception of smell. Incorrect Options: Option A - Ammonia is used for testing olfactory nerve: Ammonia is not typically used for testing the olfactory nerve as it can also stimulate the trigeminal nerve. Instead, specific odorants or substances with distinct smells, such as coffee or essential oils, are commonly used in olfactory testing to assess the function of the olfactory nerve. Option B - The olfaction system is not damaged: If the patient is unable to smell coffee after head trauma but can smell ammonia, it suggests a specific impairment in detecting certain odors, indicating damage or dysfunction in the olfaction system. Option D - All of the above: This statement is incorrect because only option C is correct. Option A and B are incorrect as explained above. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery ?
questions.explanation: branch of the ophthalmic artery. The ophthalmic artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery. Incorrect Options: Option B - 2: Structure marked as 2 is the Sphenopalatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. Maxillary artery is a branch of external carotid artery. Option C - 3: Structure marked as 3 is the greater palatine artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. Option D - 4: Structure marked as 4 is Superior labial artery, it is a branch of the facial artery.Which is also a branch of external carotid artery Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has a prior history of trauma and is currently experiencing symptoms such as double vision, nosebleeds, and limited eye movements, based on the provided CT image?
questions.explanation: contents of the orbit herniating down (teardrop sign) and a hematoma in the maxillary sinus; of the given options, the most likely option that fits the description of this injury is a blow-out fracture. Incorrect Options: Option A - Le-fort fracture: Le-fort I would show a trans maxillary fracture. Le-fort II and III involve fractures of the floor of the orbit, but in addition to this, teeth and the nasal bone are involved in Le-fort II, and an extensive mid-facial discontinuity between the midface and base of the cranium is seen in Le-fort III. Option B - Fracture maxilla: A fracture of the maxilla is a break in the top jawbone. Option C - Fracture zygomatic: This would show a defect/dip in the lateral orbital wall and may or may not involve the floor of the orbit. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: In patients with Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma, what is the primary cause of hearing loss?
questions.explanation: dysfunction of the Eustachian tube due to tumor growth. This obstruction can impair the normal ventilation and drainage of the middle ear, leading to the accumulation of fluid (serous otitis media) in the middle ear cavity, causing conductive deafness in these patients. (A component of trotter’s triad) Trotter's Triad: Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube Ipsilateral temporo-parietal neuralgia due to 5 nerve involvement Palatal paralysis (10 nerve involvement) Incorrect Options: Options A, B and D are not the primary cause of deafness in patients with NPC. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 15-year-old male patient who has a nasal mass extending to the cheek, causing one-sided obstruction and occasional nosebleeds?
questions.explanation: diagnosis is nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, it is a rare and benign tumor of nasopharynx exclusively seen in juvenile age group. It is the most common tumor of the nasopharynx and is exclusively seen in males. Angiofibroma is a highly vascular, and present with epistaxis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Nasal polyp: Nasal polyps are benign growths that usually arise from the lining of the nasal cavity and sinuses. They do not readily cause epistaxis. Option C - Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically occurs in the nasopharynx (Fossa of Rosenmuller). It is usually associated with cervical lymphadenopathy and Trotters triad. Option D - Inverted Papilloma: Inverted papilloma is a benign tumor that arises from the lining of the nasal cavity. While it can cause nasal obstruction and ocassional nasal bleed,it is more common in males of 40-70 years of age. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What could be the diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who was involved in a road traffic accident, did not wear a helmet, experienced a brief loss of consciousness, and later presented to the ENT department with complaints of clear fluid discharge from her nose after 2 days?

options.B: Infection due to hemosinus because of RTA

questions.explanation: (cerebrospinal fluid) rhinorrhea. CSF rhinorrhea refers to the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the nose due to a fracture or injury to the skull base. The history of a road traffic accident, loss of consciousness, and the subsequent clear fluid discharge from the nose are consistent with CSF rhinorrhea. Incorrect Options: Option A - Allergic rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is characterized by inflammation of the nasal passages, sneezing, itching, and nasal congestion. It is not typically associated with a trauma or injury. Option B - Infection due to hemosinus because of RTA: While an infection can occur as a complication of a fracture or injury to the sinus caused by a road traffic accident (RTA), the immediate clear fluid discharge from the nose suggests CSF leakage rather than an infection. Option D - Post-traumatic rhinitis: Clear fluid discharge from the nose, especially following a head injury and loss of consciousness, is more indicative of CSF rhinorrhea than post-traumatic rhinitis. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the ideal investigation of choice for confirming CSF rhinorrhea ?
questions.explanation: cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea is Beta 2 transferrin analysis Beta 2 transferrin is a specific marker for cerebrospinal fluid. Beta 2 transferrin is a glycoprotein found in high concentrations in the cerebrospinal fluid. It is not found in mucus or saliva. Testing the fluid obtained from the nasal discharge for the presence of beta 2 transferrin can confirm the presence of CSF rhinorrhea. Incorrect Options: Option B - CT-cisternogram: CT-cisternogram is a specialized imaging technique that can be used to detect CSF leaks. It involves injecting a contrast dye into the spinal fluid and then performing a CT scan to visualize the flow of the contrast material. While it is a useful diagnostic tool, it is more invasive and typically not the first-line investigation for suspected CSF rhinorrhea. Option C - Nasal endoscopy: Nasal endoscopy can identify the site of CSF leakage and is useful for evaluating the nasal passages and sinus openings. However, it does not directly confirm the presence of CSF in the nasal discharge. Option D - MRI with contrast: MRI with contrast can help visualize structures in the nasal and sinus region, but it may not always clearly show the presence of CSF leakage. Additionally, it is not specific for confirming CSF rhinorrhea. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is the most constant and largest ethmoidal air cells?
questions.explanation: ethmoidal. It is situated behind the uncinate process. Incorrect Options: Option A - Agger nasi cell: This tiny anterior ethmoidal air cell is located next to the frontonasal recess in the anterior section of the ethmoid sinus. The Agger Nasi is the anterior most or the 1st ethmoid air cell. Option C - Haller cell: If there is an air cell present on the floor of the orbit, then the cell is known as the Haller cell. A Haller cell can be anterior or posterior. If there is an ethmoidal air cell that is inferomedial to the orbit, it is the Haller cell. Option D - Onodi cell: The Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid sinus in the posterior and lateral directions. Sometimes, these cells may have an optic nerve within them. Sometimes, it may also contain Internal Carotid Artery. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which of the following is implicated as the cause of office headaches ?
questions.explanation: affected sinus and has characteristic periodicity, which comes up on waking, increases gradually and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding. So it is also known as an “office headache” due to its presence only during office hours. Incorrect Options: Option A, B and D are not implicated in causing pain in the forehead and, hence, do not cause office headaches. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the treatment method that is most commonly recommended for a patient diagnosed with advanced nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.explanation: nasopharyngeal carcinoma depends on various factors, including the stage of the cancer, the extent of spread, the patient's overall health, and individual considerations. However, in general, the preferred treatment approach for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is chemoradiotherapy. This approach has shown the best outcomes for nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients. It helps to address both the primary tumor in the nasopharynx as well as any potential spread of cancer cells to nearby lymph nodes or distant sites. Treatment for NPC based on stage: Stages 1 and 2: Radiotherapy is curative Stages 3 and 4: Chemo-radiotherapy IMRT (Intensity modulated radiotherapy) Incorrect Options: Option A - Surgical Excision: The main indication for surgical treatment is residual and recurrent tumors after radiotherapy or radio-chemotherapy, both in the nasopharynx and cervical lymph nodes. It can also be used for primary, limited, radio-resistant tumors. Option B - Radiotherapy: It can be used alone or in combination with other modalities like chemotherapy. Radiotherapy is particularly effective in the early stages. Option C - Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is mainly used in combination with radiotherapy in advanced stages. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Epstein Barr Virus is attributed to the pathogenesis of which of the following?
questions.explanation: associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) infection, particularly in endemic regions such as southern China, parts of Africa, and among the Inuit population of the Arctic. EBV has a significant role in the development of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, as confirmed by the virus's consistent presence in tumor cells worldwide where NPC occurs. Patients affected by NPC exhibit consistently elevated antibody titers to viral capsid antigens, which indicates recent or active EBV infection. The clonal structure of the viral genome within individual tumors suggests that EBV infection occurred before tumor development, implicating the virus in the pathogenesis of NPC. However, despite the universal presence of EBV in NPC cases worldwide, the tumor's restricted geographic distribution suggests that genetic or environmental cofactors also contribute to its development Incorrect Options: Option A - Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign tumor that primarily affects adolescent males. It arises from the vascular tissues in the back of the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. However, it is not caused by the Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). The exact cause of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is unknown, but hormonal and genetic factors are believed to play a role. Option C - Stewart's granuloma: Stewart's granuloma, also known as lobular capillary hemangioma or pyogenic granuloma, is a benign vascular tumor that can occur in various locations, including the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. It is not caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). Option D - Rhinoscleroma: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by the bacterium Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It primarily affects the nasal cavity and nasopharynx. It is not caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV). Rhinoscleroma is more commonly seen in regions with poor hygiene and sanitation. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: What is the most frequently reported symptom of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma?
questions.explanation: presenting features in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC). The lymph nodes in the apex of the posterior triangle and the upper jugular region are often the first to be involved, along with retropharyngeal nodes. Supraclavicular nodes are the last to be involved and are a sign of advanced disease. The most common lymph node involved is LN between the angle of the jaw and mastoid and LN along the spinal accessory and in the posterior triangle of the HO’s triangle. Incorrect Options: Option A - Nasal obstruction: Nasal obstruction can be a symptom of nasopharyngeal carcinoma, but it is not the most common presenting complaint. Other conditions, such as allergies, sinusitis, or nasal polyps, are more commonly associated with nasal obstruction. However, as the tumor grows in the nasopharynx, it can eventually cause nasal obstruction. Option B - Epistaxis: Epistaxis, or nosebleeds, can occur in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. However, it is not the most common presenting complaint. Option D - Anosmia: Anosmia in nasopharyngeal carcinoma can occur due to nasal obstruction. This is more common in advanced and large tumors. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 31-year-old presents with complains of tenderness just above the medial canthus. A condition that presents with "Office headache". What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: frontal sinusitis. Office headache: headache in morning and no headache in evening. Incorrect options: Option B. In maxillary sinusitis, the Pain is characterized by aggravation on leaning forward or stooping forward. Option C. Migraine headaches are characterized by an aura (classical) and sensory disturbances. Pain occurs mainly unilaterally. Option D. In temporal arteritis, Pain mainly occurs in the temporal region. Pain is usually frequent and severe. Tenderness is also present over temples. Reference: Diseases of ENT by Dl Dhingra
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: The frontal sinus can be viewed by taking an X-ray at a specific angle, which is depicted in the image below. What is the name of the view depicted?
questions.explanation: X-ray beam passing from behind the head at an angle of 15° to the radiographic plate. This description aligns with Caldwell's view, which is primarily used for assessing the frontal and ethmoidal sinuses as well as the nasal septum. Incorrect Options: Option B - Towne’s view: In this view X-ray beam is passed from above in front at an angle of 30° to the radiographic plate. It is mainly used to visualize the petrous part of the temporal bone and the posterior part of sella turcica. It is used to assess any fracture to the floor of the cranium, acoustic neuroma, and apical petrositis Option C - Law’s view: It is a lateral oblique view of the mastoid. The patient lies in such a way that the sagittal plane of the skull is parallel to the film, and the X-ray beam is projected 15°cephalocaudal. Structures seen are (a) External auditory canal superimposed on the internal auditory canal. (b) Mastoid air cells. (c) Tegmen. (d) Lateral sinus plate. (e) Temporomandibular joint. “Key area” of the mastoid, i.e., attic, aditus, and antrum, is not well seen. Option D - Stenver’s view: This view is taken in such a way that the long axis of the petrous bone lies parallel to the film. Structures seen are: (a) Entire petrous pyramid. (b) Arcuate eminence. (c) Internal auditory meatus. (d) Labyrinth with its vestibule. (e) Cochlea. (f) Mastoid antrum
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass has filled the nasal cavity and eroded the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: nasal discharge, a black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity, eroding the septum, and a hard palate is most likely suffering from mucormycosis. A class of molds known as mucormycetes is the source of mucormycosis. Mucormycosis is rapid growing disease involving the arteries and causing endothelial damage and thrombosis. Immunocompromised people are more likely to develop mucormycosis, such as those with uncontrolled diabetes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Aspergillosis: Aspergillus species can produce similar symptoms. Rather than black necrotic mass fungal ball containing cheesy-white or blackish material is usually observed. Option C - Foreign body: Neither a black necrotic mass nor a foul-smelling discharge would be caused by a foreign body. Option D - Rhinosporidiosis: Rhinosporidiosis is a very uncommon chronic illness brought on by Rhinosporidium seeberi, and it usually manifests as a painless, slowly expanding nasal polyp, which is inconsistent with the symptoms that are being reported. Reference: Tuli's Textook of Ear, Nose and Throat
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy and right ear pain. On examination, the right ear reveals conductive hearing loss with a dull tympanic membrane. Moreover, decreased mobility of the soft palate was also noted. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Triad, which is associated with malignant nasopharyngeal carcinoma invading the lateral wall. Trotter's Triad : Conductive deafness due to block of eustachian tube · Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to V th nerve involvement. Palatal paralysis (10 nerve involvement) It is diagnostic of nasopharyngeal carcinoma Incorrect Options: Option B - Adenoid cystic cancer: Typically, adenoid cystic cancer develops in the salivary glands without showing any symptoms like conductive hearing loss or restricted soft palate movement. Option C - Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Adolescent males are typically affected by juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, a rare non-cancerous tumor that seldom results in symptoms like conductive hearing loss or restricted soft palate mobility. Option D - Quinsy: Quinsy, also known as peritonsillar abscess, is a complication of tonsillitis that results in a severe sore throat, fever, and trouble swallowing but does not frequently cause symptoms like conductive hearing loss or constrained soft palate movement. Reference: Prepladder Notes
questions.chapter_heading: Nose And Paranasal Sinuses-Previous Year Questions

questions.question: Which fungal infection is frequently observed in the maxillary sinus?
questions.explanation: sinus, caused by Aspergillus fumigatus. Incorrect Options: Option A - Blastomycosis: It is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. In immunocompetent, it primarily causes pulmonary infections and skin lesions, and in immunocompromised, it causes CNS infections. Option C - Candidiasis : It mainly causes opportunistic infections, with diabetes mellitus being the most common predisposing factor. It is often implicated in cutaneous, mucosal, intestinal, bronchopulmonary, and systemic infections. Option D - Histoplasmosis: Histoplasma capsulatum is a species of fungus that causes histoplasmosis. It is primarily a pulmonary infection but can also cause cutaneous and disseminated disease. It can cause infection in both immunocompetent and compromised patients. Histoplasma-causing sinusitis is uncommon. Reference: Prepladder Notes
